Literary narratives key to doctoring

Group uses stories to improve medical practice

  • By Laura Montini
  • reesenews multimedia journalist
Dec. 02 12:00 pm
  • 68233 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F2010%2F12%2F02%2Fnarrative-medicine%2F6823%2FLiterary+narratives+key+to+doctoring2010-12-02+17%3A00%3A48Laura+Montinihttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F%3Fp%3D6823
  • E-mail
  • Print

Do you like this story?

DURHAM
Every Friday at noon, hospital staff from different departments of Duke University Medical Center gather in a small room at the Duke Clinic for one hour.

Members read literary works, invite guest authors and poets to the table, and once a month they share their own works — all for the sake of practicing better medicine.

Grey Brown discusses the story "What You Pawn, I will Redeem," at the Osler Literary Roundtable.

Physicians, physician assistants, lab researchers, students and medical community members sit side by side and discuss the week’s poem or short story at the Osler Literary Roundtable.

The goals of the group align with a larger movement to help doctors use the liberal arts in their practices.

The Roundtable is based on the idea of practicing narrative medicine, which incorporates literature and personal stories in order to gain a better understanding of patients and their life experiences.

Terrence Holt, an assistant professor for the UNC Department of Social Medicine, said that physicians have seen pressures in the work environment come between them and their patients.

He said that this discontent has led to the reintegration of the medical humanities.

“Maybe a doctor needs to be something more than somebody who got A’s in biochemistry as an undergraduate. Maybe what you need is somebody who has some understanding of the human heart,” he said.

One worry is that doctors are often too rushed to have real conversations with patients about their illnesses.

The Roundtable allows doctors to practice receiving and interpreting stories.

“Narrative is at the heart of the caregiver-patient relationship,” said Grey Brown, Roundtable member and co-founder of the literary arts program for the Health Arts Network at Duke.

“When patients come in, we ask them for their stories, and if you can read literature and understand the hidden meanings, then you hone your skills as a person who receives patient narrative,” she said.

Not all works discussed at the Roundtable are overtly medical, said Francis Neelon, a retired endocrinologist and medical director of the Rice Diet Program in Durham.

For instance, members recently read “What You Pawn, I Will Redeem,” a short story by Sherman Alexie about a homeless Native American living in Seattle, Wash.

“In the larger sense, every time you’re reading something and interpreting it and understanding it, you are in the business of medicine,” Neelon said.

The Roundtable has met since 1987, incorporating aspects of narrative medicine even as the term began to emerge in the past decade.

Rita Charon, a general internist who holds a Ph.D. in English, founded the first Program in Narrative Medicine in 2000 at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. The program offers a master’s degree in the field.

“It’s a clinical practice fortified with the skills of knowing what to do with stories,” Charon said.

“How to receive them, how to interpret them, how to metabolize them and how to tell them. But certainly how to receive them from sick people who try so desperately to tell them.”

Duke University School of Medicine and the UNC School of Medicine do not offer formal training in narrative medicine, but Ray Barfield, a pediatric oncologist at Duke, is working on forming a program.

Barfield said it would be ideal for Duke and UNC to combine resources to educate students.

The challenge is figuring out when this approach should be integrated into a medical student’s education, he said.

Last year, Barfield took the first step by working with a medical student to create a program through the Duke Divinity School that incorporates aspects of narrative medicine. This year there are two other students in the program.

Barfield teaches by example and allows students to work with him in Duke’s intensive care unit. But through reading literature, his independent-study students also learn to listen and interpret patients’ stories.

“Nobody’s reducible to their illness,” he said. “The habit of listening to stories and the habit of telling stories is a great way to move a step beyond just focusing on the biology of disease.”

For example, Barfield said that if a patient comes to him with a hand problem, but he fails to learn that his patient is a classical pianist, he has missed an important point.

“I don’t understand that every day you don’t practice, you feel you’re losing your identity,” Barfield said.

Holt, a supporter of narrative medicine, said that literature can give doctors insight into experiences, cultures and beliefs that they have never dealt with in their own lives.

“One of the challenges in medical education these days is that we’re dealing with an increasingly heterogeneous population,” Holt said.

“Literature gives you a much better handle on how you’re going to work well with people whose experiences are very different from yours.”

Holt said that though he is decades younger than most of the patients he treats in geriatrics, literary works help him understand seniors who come to him with complicated medical histories.

“Literature knows things that we don’t and manages to get it across in ways we don’t understand,” Holt said.

Neelon, who was one of the first members of the Roundtable, said that narrative medicine isn’t a new concept.

The goal is to make sense of a patient’s story the same way a reader tries to understand a written work.

“I’ve always thought that was really the task of what doctoring was,” he said. “They’ve given a new name to something that was very old.”

Barfield said he didn’t have any formal training in guiding people through their medical crisis and was forced to learn on the job.

“You show up at the crisis armed with all of this knowledge about the biology of what’s going on in the person, and with almost no training in how to help a real human being,” Barfield said.

He said that while working with dying AIDS patients during his residency, his senior resident advised him to “cut the heart strings” rather than become emotionally invested.

“That was my first real encounter with how high the stakes are and how deeply intense the stories are of people in front of me,” Barfield said.

Erik Becker, a fourth-year medical student at Duke, studied with Barfield last year.

He said that the work he did with Barfield helped him gain insight into the ways he can communicate and empathize with patients.

“It’s unfortunate that these issues are given such short shrift during med school, but I understand that students will shape their experiences to suit their personalities, and this isn’t for everyone,” he said.

Neelon said that some physicians don’t see the practices of the Roundtable as directly related to medicine or the mission of Duke Hospital.

“It’s not always obvious to everyone,” he said. “But I think it’s helpful, and so we’ve kept it going for all this time.”

Laura Montini, a senior from Ramsey, N.J., is a multimedia journalist for the Reese Felts Digital News Project.

    Comment by C.GARRISON on December 3, 2010 at 7:28 pm

  2. Very interesting concept but many physicians are excellent empathetic communicators now. I think modern methods of communication (non face to face talking) are impacting genuine compassionate communication in all aspects of society.

    Comment by Julie Ballance MD on December 8, 2010 at 10:41 am

  3. Excellent work. I am a recovering triple bypass heart patient and my own story and others reveals that the doctor never heard us. I am writing about this and more at my blog, http://www.allheartmatters.com. I also recently authored a story, "The Empty Heart found at the Yale Journal for Humanties in Medicine.

    Thank you.
    James Borton
